steps.content: Of the cities within the United States where U.S. presidents were born, which two are the farthest apart from the westernmost to the easternmost going east, giving the city names only? Give them to me in alphabetical order, in a comma-separated list

plan: Identify the cities in the United States where U.S. presidents were born.
Determine the geographical coordinates (longitude) of each city.
Find the westernmost and easternmost cities based on their longitudes.
Select the two cities that are the farthest apart from each other, one being the westernmost and the other the easternmost.
Sort the names of these two cities alphabetically.
Format the final answer as a comma-separated list.

Title: List of presidents of the United States by home state - Wikipedia
=======================
# List of presidents of the United States by home state

These lists give the [states](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") of primary affiliation and of birth for each [president](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States") of the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States").

Birthplaces
-----------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_home_state&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Birthplaces")]
Twenty-one states have the distinction of being the birthplace of a president.

One president's birth state is in dispute; North and South Carolina (British colonies at the time) both lay claim to [Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson"), who was born in 1767 in the [Waxhaw region](/wiki/Waxhaws "Waxhaws") along their common border. Jackson himself considered South Carolina his birth state.[[1]](#cite_note-1)

Born on December 5, 1782, [Martin Van Buren](/wiki/Martin_Van_Buren "Martin Van Buren") was the first president born an [American citizen](/wiki/American_citizen "American citizen") (and not a [British subject](/wiki/British_subject "British subject")).[[2]](#cite_note-2)

The term [Virginia dynasty](/wiki/Virginia_dynasty "Virginia dynasty") is sometimes used to describe the fact that four of the first five U.S. presidents were from Virginia.

The number of presidents per state in which they were born, counting Jackson as being from South Carolina, are:

* One: [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas"), [California](/wiki/California "California"), [Connecticut](/wiki/Connecticut "Connecticut"), [Georgia](/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state) "Georgia (U.S. state)"), [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii"), [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois"), [Iowa](/wiki/Iowa "Iowa"), [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky"), [Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri"), [Nebraska](/wiki/Nebraska "Nebraska"), [New Hampshire](/wiki/New_Hampshire "New Hampshire"), [New Jersey](/wiki/New_Jersey "New Jersey"), and [South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina")
* Two: [North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina"), [Pennsylvania](/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania"), [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas"), and [Vermont](/wiki/Vermont "Vermont")
* Four: [Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts "Massachusetts")
* Five: [New York](/wiki/New_York_(state) "New York (state)")
* Seven: [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio")
* Eight: [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia")

| Date of birth | President | Birthplace | State[†](#endnote_state_colony) of birth | In office |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| February 22, 1732 | [George Washington](/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington") | [Popes Creek](/wiki/George_Washington_Birthplace_National_Monument "George Washington Birthplace National Monument") | [Virginia](/wiki/Colony_of_Virginia "Colony of Virginia")[†](#endnote_state_colony) | (1st) April 30, 1789 – March 4, 1797 |
| October 30, 1735 | [John Adams](/wiki/John_Adams "John Adams") | [Braintree](/wiki/Braintree,_Massachusetts "Braintree, Massachusetts") | [Massachusetts](/wiki/Province_of_Massachusetts_Bay "Province of Massachusetts Bay")[†](#endnote_state_colony) | (2nd) March 4, 1797 – March 4, 1801 |
| April 13, 1743\* | [Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson") | [Shadwell](/wiki/Shadwell,_Virginia "Shadwell, Virginia") | Virginia[†](#endnote_state_colony) | (3rd) March 4, 1801 – March 4, 1809 |
| March 16, 1751 | [James Madison](/wiki/James_Madison "James Madison") | [Port Conway](/wiki/Port_Conway,_Virginia "Port Conway, Virginia") | Virginia[†](#endnote_state_colony) | (4th) March 4, 1809 – March 4, 1817 |
| April 28, 1758 | [James Monroe](/wiki/James_Monroe "James Monroe") | [Monroe Hall](/wiki/Monroe_Hall,_Virginia "Monroe Hall, Virginia") | Virginia[†](#endnote_state_colony) | (5th) March 4, 1817 – March 4, 1825 |
| March 15, 1767 | [Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson") | [Waxhaws](/wiki/Waxhaws "Waxhaws") Region | [South Carolina](/wiki/Province_of_South_Carolina "Province of South Carolina")[†](#endnote_state_colony) | (7th) March 4, 1829 – March 4, 1837 |
| July 11, 1767 | [John Quincy Adams](/wiki/John_Quincy_Adams "John Quincy Adams") | [Braintree](/wiki/Braintree,_Massachusetts "Braintree, Massachusetts") | Massachusetts[†](#endnote_state_colony) | (6th) March 4, 1825 – March 4, 1829 |

| February 12, 1809 | [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln") | [Hodgenville](/wiki/Hodgenville,_Kentucky "Hodgenville, Kentucky") | [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky") | (16th) March 4, 1861 – April 15, 1865 |
| April 27, 1822 | [Ulysses S. Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S. Grant") | [Point Pleasant](/wiki/Point_Pleasant,_Ohio "Point Pleasant, Ohio") | [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio") | (18th) March 4, 1869 – March 4, 1877 |
| October 4, 1822 | [Rutherford B. Hayes](/wiki/Rutherford_B._Hayes "Rutherford B. Hayes") | [Delaware](/wiki/Delaware,_Ohio "Delaware, Ohio") | [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio") | (19th) March 4, 1877 – March 4, 1881 |

| September 15, 1857 | [William Howard Taft](/wiki/William_Howard_Taft "William Howard Taft") | [Cincinnati](/wiki/Cincinnati "Cincinnati") | [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio") | (27th) March 4, 1909 – March 4, 1913 |
| October 27, 1858 | [Theodore Roosevelt](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt "Theodore Roosevelt") | [Gramercy Park](/wiki/Gramercy_Park "Gramercy Park") | [New York](/wiki/New_York_(state) "New York (state)") | (26th) September 14, 1901 – March 4, 1909 |
| November 2, 1865 | [Warren G. Harding](/wiki/Warren_G._Harding "Warren G. Harding") | [Blooming Grove](/wiki/Blooming_Grove,_Ohio "Blooming Grove, Ohio") | [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio") | (29th) March 4, 1921 – August 2, 1923 |

| August 10, 1874 | [Herbert Hoover](/wiki/Herbert_Hoover "Herbert Hoover") | [West Branch](/wiki/West_Branch,_Iowa "West Branch, Iowa") | [Iowa](/wiki/Iowa "Iowa") | (31st) March 4, 1929 – March 4, 1933 |

Presidential birthplace and early childhood historic sites
----------------------------------------------------------

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_home_state&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Presidential birthplace and early childhood historic sites")]
The birthplaces and early childhood residences of many U.S. presidents have been preserved or replicated. In instances where a physical structure is absent, a monument or roadside marker has been erected to denote the site's historic significance. All sites in the table below are listed in the [National Register of Historic Places](/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of Historic Places").

A dramatic shift in childbirth from home to hospital occurred in the United States in the early 20th century (mid–1920s to 1940).[[4]](#cite_note-4) Reflective of this trend, Jimmy Carter and all presidents born during and after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") ([Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") and every president since) have been born in a hospital, not a private residence. This sortable table is ordered by the presidents' birthdates.

### Notes

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_home_state&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Notes")]

1. **[^](#cite_ref-5)** Taylor spent his entire childhood in Louisville, commissioned the Kentuckian 7th Infantry Regiment at [Terre aux Boeufs](/wiki/St._Bernard_Parish,_Louisiana "St. Bernard Parish, Louisiana"), and is buried in a cemetery in Louisville named after him. According to *Zachary Taylor: The American Presidents Series: The 12th President, 1849–1850* states on p. 11 ~ "Taylor's *home state* of Kentucky,..."
2. **[^](#cite_ref-6)** Eisenhower held residency in New York during the [1952 presidential election](/wiki/1952_United_States_presidential_election "1952 United States presidential election") and later in Pennsylvania during the [1956 presidential election](/wiki/1956_United_States_presidential_election "1956 United States presidential election"), but was primarily raised in Kansas and later settled back there.
3. **[^](#cite_ref-7)** For a brief period whilst working as a lawyer, Nixon identified his home state as New York and won the [1968 presidential election](/wiki/1968_United_States_presidential_election "1968 United States presidential election") as a resident, but he later reclaimed residency in California (where he was born, and served previously as a U.S. senator) early into his first term.
4. **[^](#cite_ref-8)** • *Trump Revealed: The Definitive Biography of the 45th President* (Kranish, Michael) p. 124 ~ "Trump had hoped his **home state** of [New York](/wiki/New_York_(state) "New York (state)")..."
• *The Elections of 2016* (Nelson, Michael) p. 50 ~ "the next primary on the Republican calendar was in New York, Trump's **home state**"
5. **[^](#cite_ref-9)** Trump's official state of residence was [New York](/wiki/New_York_(state) "New York (state)") in the [2016 presidential election](/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election "2016 United States presidential election"), but it was changed to [Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida") when his permanent residence was switched from [Trump Tower](/wiki/Trump_Tower "Trump Tower") to [Mar-a-Lago](/wiki/Mar-a-Lago "Mar-a-Lago") in 2019.

Honolulu, HI, USA
=================

Latitude and longitude coordinates are: **21\.315603, \-157\.858093**.

Honolulu is the capital and one of the most populous cities of Hawaii which is a remote state in the USA. The city is a popular resort and a destination for those who dream about a world\-class vacation on the ocean shores. Located in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, the city has been inhabited since the early ages. As the evidence shows, the city has been a permanent settlement since about the 12th century. Honolulu is a historic center and the key tourist hub of the state. At the same time, it is a known business center with numerous business corporations and companies.

The remote location of the city does not change much as to the development and is connected with the rest of the world for the people of Honolulu and Hawaii. The capital city of the country is primarily known as the center of education and health care of the whole state, with the best hospitals, clinics, schools, colleges, and those few universities located in the state. Honolulu is undoubtedly the center of cultural life, with plenty of galleries, museums, arts schools, theaters, and venues for various musical and cultural events. The traditions and lifestyle of the local people are unique, but most of the guests of Honolulu say that unique local cuisine was among the most unforgettable and special parts of the cultural life that they've got to know.

New York City, NY, USA
======================

Latitude and longitude coordinates are: **40\.730610, \-73\.935242**.

New York City is one of the most known cities\-symbols of the USA located in the northeastern part of the country, on the Atlantic coast. It is known as a global business capital city and one of the most populous, developed, innovative, and bustling cities of the world. New York is a true wonder of the US, and it can open its secrets and beautiful atmosphere to anyone who comes to visit it. It is located on the mouth of the Hudson River and is a destination for all kinds of tourists and guests, from business people to various tourists seeking some rest and new adventures.

The city has 5 famous central boroughs like Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, and others, and it is also known as the city located on one of the largest natural harbors on the continent. The city is home to some most visited tourist attractions of the world including Central Park, Times Square, the Metropolitan Museum of Arts, the Broadway Theater, and many more.
